Acid-base bifunctional catalysis represents a significant approach for achieving enzyme-like catalytic activity. In this study, we present a concise and direct approach for constructing acid-base bifunctional aramid fiber catalysts, enabling one-pot tandem deacetalization-Knoevenagel reactions in an aqueous environment. The fiber catalysts were conveniently prepared from commercially available aramid fiber using a straightforward two-step procedure, and comprehensively characterized using various detection techniques. Additionally, the acid-base cooperativity of the AF catalyst was effectively controlled through the manipulation of the acid-base ratios within the catalysts. Notably, the AF-SN1/2 catalyst exhibited superior catalytic activity in the one-pot tandem deprotection-Knoevenagel reaction at room temperature, resulting in the production of high yields. Moreover, the AF-SN1/2 catalyst demonstrated exceptional recyclability and performed admirably in a scaled-up experiment utilizing a straightforward fixed-bed reactor. These findings suggest that the AF-SN1/2 catalyst holds significant promise for future applications in cleaner industrial processes. Consequently, cascade reactions, characterized by the amalgamation of two or more autonomous reactions, have gained significant traction in recent years due to their advantageous attributes such as enhanced atom economy, diminished energy consumption, streamlined synthetic protocols, and time efficiency [3–6]. As one of the most well-known, deacetalization-Knoevenagel condensation is a widely recognized cascade reaction facilitated by cooperative acid-base catalysts, necessitates the initial involvement of an acid catalyst to catalyze deacetalization, succeeded by a base catalyst to facilitate the Knoevenagel condensation [7–9]. In recent times, considerable focus has been directed towards the utilization of acid-base bifunctional catalysts in tandem reactions. Nevertheless, challenges such as restricted reusability, product segregation, and particularly the self-neutralization of active acidic and basic sites in homogeneous acid-base bifunctional catalysts hinder the attainment of high reaction efficiency [10]. These problems can be effectively addressed through the utilization of a heterogeneous acid-base catalyst that possesses spatially isolated catalytic active sites. This approach offers the advantages of enhanced catalytic efficiency and increased product yield. To achieve this, the catalyst can be designed and synthesized by incorporating appropriate acidic and basic sites onto support materials such as carbon [11,12], graphene [13], mesoporous silica material [10,14], boron nitride [15–17], covalent organic framework [9], metal-organic framework [1,18-20], graphitic carbon nitride [21–24], magnetic nanoparticle [25], among others. For example, Yanjing Hu et al. have successfully synthesized a bimetallic metal-organic framework that has been functionalized with amines. This framework has exhibited remarkable stability, exceptional recyclability, and enduring catalytic activity in the context of deacetalization-Knoevenagel condensation [19]. Similarly, Priyanka Choudhary et al. have developed a highly versatile and efficient heterogeneous catalyst (S-g-C3N4) by introducing -SO3H groups onto g-C3N4 nanosheets. Their findings highlight the significant contribution of the dual acid-base sites on the catalyst to the overall reaction process [24]. However, certain acid-base bifunctional catalysts that have been documented exhibit drawbacks such as exorbitant expenses, limited reusability, diminished catalytic efficacy, and laborious preparation procedures. Consequently, there is a pressing need to conduct further research on identifying more stable and efficient support materials for the heterogenization of acid-base bifunctional catalysts. Aramid fiber (AF) is a technologically advanced synthetic fiber that consists of a minimum of 85% amide links connecting two aromatic rings. Due to its exceptional comprehensive characteristics, such as high specific strength, low density, resistance to high temperatures and aging, chemical stability, and high specific modulus, AF has garnered significant attention from researchers and has found extensive applications in various industries, including body armor, protective clothing, weaponry, and equipment, as well as the aerospace and automotive sectors [26–29]. Furthermore, AF exhibits a substantial presence of electron-rich benzene rings, rendering it highly amenable to grafting with sulfonyl, chloromethyl, amino, and other functional groups through suitable chemical reactions. Additionally, its versatility in being knitted into diverse shapes makes it exceptionally well-suited for implementation in fixed-bed reactors during industrial production. Undoubtedly, AF emerges as a promising support material for the preparation of heterogeneous catalysts. In our previous research, we have designed and developed a range of heterogeneous catalysts based on polyacrylonitrile fiber (PANF) for various organic reactions. These catalysts have exhibited several advantageous characteristics, particularly in terms of their ease of use and ability to be recycled [30–34]. However, it is important to note that PANF-based catalysts have certain limitations, such as their intolerance to strong acids/alkalis and their poor resistance to polar aprotic solvents (e.g., DMF, DMSO, etc.). These drawbacks consequently limit their potential applications. Based on our previous works on fiber catalysts, a novel acid-base bifunctional catalyst has been developed in this work by incorporating a sulfonic acid and tertiary amine dual-functionalization into an AF-based fiber catalyst which demonstrates remarkable activity and reusability in catalyzing the deacetalization-Knoevenagel condensation. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthesis of the fiber catalysts Step 1 3 g AF, 80 mL cyclohexane was introduced into a three-necked flask with a condenser (the condenser top attached with a balloon), and the mixture was preheated to reflux and stir for 4 h. After the above mixture was cooled to room temperature, the fiber was filtered out and immersed into 80 mL ethanol and stirred at 80 °C for 4 h. Whereafter, the fiber sample was filtered out and repeatedly washed with ethanol (3 × 20 mL), and then the fiber was dried to constant weight at 60 °C under vacuum. Step 2 2 mL chlorosulfonic acid was introduced into a three-necked flask with a condenser (the condenser top attached with a balloon), and the solution was cooled to -10 °C with stirring. Then, 1 g washed and dried AF was immersed into the above solution and stirred for 10 min. Next, the AF was picked up with a tweezer and quickly dropped into 30 mL N, N-dimethyl-1,3-propanediamine, and the formed mixture was stirred at 80 °C for a certain time. Whereafter, the fiber was filtered out and repeatedly washed with water (3 × 20 mL), and then the fiber was added to 50 mL water and stirred at 80 °C for 1 h. Finally, the modified fiber was dried overnight under vacuum at 60 °C to give the acid-base bifunctional catalyst AF-SO3H-N(Me)2 . 2.2 General procedure for one-pot tandem deacetalization-Knoevenagel condensation reaction A mixture of benzaldehyde acetal (1 mmol), malononitrile (1.2 mmol), AF-SN (5 mol%, sum of both acid and base groups based on acetal), and water (5 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 2.5 h. After completion of the reaction, the fiber catalyst was taken out with a tiny pair of tweezers and washed with EtOAc (3 × 10 mL), which was a combined reaction aqueous solution to the mixture. The mixture was stirred until all organic solids had dissolved. After being dried with anhydrous Na2SO4, the purified product was finally obtained by column chromatography (petroleum ether/ethyl acetate). 2.3 General procedure for scaled-up experiment with a simple fixed-bed reactor A mixture of benzaldehyde dimethylacetal (100 mmol), malononitrile (120 mmol), and water (500 mL) was added to a simple spinning basket reactor with AF-SN (5 mol%, sum of both acid and base groups based on acetal) in its impellers (Figure S1). The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 2.5 h. After completion of the reaction, the mixture was dumped out and extracted with ethyl acetate (3 × 30 mL). Then, ethyl acetate (50 mL × 2) was added to the reactor to wash the fiber catalyst and the reaction vessel, which were combined with the organic phase of the previous step. After the organic phase was dried with anhydrous Na2SO4, the purified product was finally obtained by column chromatography (petroleum ether/ethyl acetate). 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Synthesis of the fiber catalysts The AF fiber was initially subjected to sequential washing with cyclohexane and ethanol to eliminate any impurities. Subsequently, the AF-SO3H, AF-SN, and AF-N(Me)2 catalysts were synthesized through a post-functionalization procedure using the washed AF. The synthesis and regulation of the bifunctional AF catalyst involved an initial modification with chlorosulfonic acid, as demonstrated in Scheme 1 . This modification introduced chlorosulfonyl groups into the fiber, enabling the formation of acid sites with sulfonic acid groups. Additionally, the chlorosulfonyl groups reacted with N, N-dimethyl-1,3-propanediamine to generate base sites with tertiary amine groups. The degree of functionality of both sulfonic acid and tertiary amine groups was carefully assessed through acid-base titration. The AF-SO2Cl compound undergoes a direct reaction with water, resulting in the formation of a sulfonic acid functional AF catalyst known as AF-SO3H, which possesses 1.98 mmol/g -SO3H groups as indicated in Table 1 , entry 1. Furthermore, the acid-base bifunctional AF catalyst can be generated by reacting AF-SO2Cl with N, N-dimethyl-1,3-propanediamine, with the acid/base ratio being adjustable through the control of reaction time. As indicated in Table 1, it is evident that a lengthier reaction time of AF-SO2Cl with N, N-dimethyl-1,3-propanediamine results in a smaller acid/base ratio. Subsequently, a total of seven distinct acid-base ratios ranging from 8:1 to 1:5 were obtained for fiber-supported acid-base bifunctional catalysts AF-SN (Table 1, entries 2–8). Additionally, it should be noted that the overall quantity of acid and base in different AF catalysts varies due to the vigorous modification process involving chlorosulfonic acid. Furthermore, a tertiary amine functional AF catalyst of AF-(Me)2 with a base content of 1.92 mmol/g was obtained when the reaction time was 8 h and the chlorosulfonyl groups were nearly consumed entirely (Table 1, entry 9). The quality of aramid fiber improves during the modification process, but the fiber structure is damaged during sulfonation and amination. As a result, the theoretical weight gain differs from the actual weight gain, making it more accurate to detect acid and base content through the acid-base drop point. 3.2 Characterization of the fiber catalysts 3.2.1 Morphologies The physical photographs of AF, AF-SO3H, AF-SN1/2, and AF-SN1/2–10 (the catalyst recovered after the 10th cycle) are depicted in Figure S2. From the apparent morphologies, the original AF exhibited a conspicuous bright yellow hue (Fig. S2a). The yellow tones of AF-SO3H and AF-SN were intensified through subsequent functionalizations during the preparation process (Fig. S2b and c). Following 10 cycles of reuse, the color of AF-SN-10 exhibited a slight shift towards orange (Fig. S2d). The fiber samples experienced gradual shrinkage, accompanied by alterations in color. Nevertheless, irrespective of the preparation or utilization of the fibers, their fibrous structure remained intact. Furthermore, the morphologies of AF, AF-SO3H, AF-SN1/2, and AF-SN1/2–10 were also examined using scanning electron microscopy (SEM). As depicted in Fig. 1 , the diameter of AF was approximately 18 μm and exhibited a remarkably smooth surface (Fig. 1a). Following sulfonation, the fiber surface displayed slight roughness and lacerations (Fig. 1a). Subsequent modification with N, N-dimethyl-1,3-propanediamine resulted in increased scarring on the surface of AF-SN1/2 (Fig. 1c). Moreover, the surface of the recovered fiber sample of AF-SN1/2–10 exhibited progressively coarser features after each sequential catalytic cycle (Fig. 1d). 3.2.2 X-ray diffraction (XRD) Additionally, the integrity of the chosen fibers was assessed using X-ray diffraction (XRD). Fig. 2 displays the XRD spectra of AF, AF-SO3H, AF-SN1/2, AF-SN1/2–1, and AF-SN1/2–10. In the XRD pattern of AF, the (110), (200), (211), and (202) planes are represented by four peaks at 2θ=20.0°, 22.1°, 24.7°, and 27.7°, respectively (Fig. 2a). Following the modification for the synthesis of the acid-base bifunctional catalyst, the reflection peaks of AF-SO3H and AF-SN1/2 exhibited a gradual decrease (Fig. 2b and 2c), indicating that the modified processes caused damage to a portion of the crystalline phase of the fibers. Upon subjecting the fiber catalyst AF-SN1/2 to 10 cycles of use, the peaks of AF-SN1/2–10 were further weakened due to the continuous rupture of bonds within its inner crystal region. Nevertheless, the AF-SN1/2–10 catalyst retained its fundamental structure. 3.2.3 Elemental analyses (EA) The EA data for the AF, AF-SO3H, AF-SN1/2 and AF-SN1/2–10 were subjected to three repetitions, and the resulting average values were computed and presented in Table S1. The elemental composition of AF, specifically the C, H, N, and S contents, were determined to be 67.78%, 4.29%, 11.76%, and 0%, respectively (Table S1, entry 1). Upon the introduction of -SO3H to the fiber, the C, H, and N contents of AF-SO3H exhibited a decrease, while the S content displayed an expected increase (Table S1, entry 2). The N, N-dimethyl-1, 3-propanediamine exhibited a lower carbon content of 58.77%, but higher hydrogen and nitrogen contents of 13.81% and 27.42% respectively. This resulted in a decrease in carbon content and an increase in hydrogen and nitrogen contents for AF-SN1/2 (Table S1, entry 3), providing evidence of the successful peparation of acid-base bifunctional catalyst. Furthermore, after being used 10 times, the EA data of AF-SN1/2–10 remained almost identical to the original AF-SN1/2 (Table S1, entry 4), indicating the excellent stability and reusability of AF-SN1/2 in the one-pot tandem reaction. 3.2.4 Fourier-transfer infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) The fiber samples underwent pulverization and were subsequently mixed into KBr pellets. The resulting spectra are presented in Fig. 3 . In the case of the AF spectrum (Fig. 3a), the presence of an absorption peak at 1646 cm−1 was attributed to the stretching vibration of the C = O bond. Additionally, two prominent characteristic peaks were observed at 1540 cm−1 and 1308 cm−1, which were assigned to the coupled deformation vibrations of CN and NH, respectively [35]. Furthermore, the presence of two absorption peaks at 824 cm−1 and 657 cm−1 in the FTIR spectrum of AF can be attributed to the characteristic bending vibrations of the benzene ring. Additionally, the absorption peak observed at 3320 cm−1 can be assigned to the unsaturated CH bond on the benzene ring of AF [27]. In contrast, the FTIR spectrum of AF-SO3H (Fig. 3b) exhibits two new peaks at 1230 cm−1 and 1012 cm−1, which can be attributed to the stretching vibrations of O=S=O and S=O bonds [36]. This observation provides evidence for the successful formation of a chemical bond between -SO3H and AF. After being modified by N, N-dimethyl-1,3-propanediamine, there have been no new peaks observed in the spectrum of AF-SN1/2, which suggests that no new organic groups were introduced to the fiber. Additionally, the characteristic absorption peaks of AF-SN1/2–1 (Fig. 3d) and AF-SN1/2–10 (Fig. 3e) closely resemble those of the fresh AF-SN1/2 (Fig. 3c), indicating the dependable performance of the acid-base bifunctional AF catalyst in catalytic cycles. 3.2.5 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) The AF and AF-SN1/2 were subjected to X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis to investigate their elemental compositions and the acid/base combination form with AF. The XPS survey spectra of AF (Fig. 4 a) revealed the presence of C, N, and O peaks, as depicted in Fig. 4. Consistent with expectations, the XPS spectrum of AF-SN1/2 exhibited the appearance of S following modification with sulfonic acid and tertiary amine groups. Additionally, the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis revealed that the surface S content of the fiber catalyst is 2.44%, which is significantly lower than the total S content of 5.87% determined by elemental analysis (EA). This discrepancy suggests that the modification of the fiber catalyst does not occur solely on the superficial layer, but extends to multiple layers, thereby contributing to the formation of catalytic microenvironments. Moreover, the C 1 s and N 1 s peaks were specifically chosen for further investigation of the acid/base functional groups (Fig. 4c-f). In the high-resolution C 1 s spectrum of the fiber catalyst, the characteristic peaks observed at 284.7 eV and 288.1 eV can be attributed to the presence of CC, CH, and CO bonds, respectively. In the high resolution C 1 s spectrum of AF-SN1/2, a distinctive peak at approximately 285.5 eV emerged as a result of the establishment of a C-S bond, as depicted in Fig. 4d. By examining the N 1 s high-resolution spectra of AF and AF-SN1/2 (Fig. 4e and f), it becomes evident that a characteristic peak corresponding to the N-S bond materialized at 402.3 eV due to the formation of sulfamide, indicating the successful synthesis of a sulfonic acid and tertiary amine bifunctional AF catalyst. 3.2.6 Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis Aramid fiber is a specialized fiber known for its high temperature resistance and exceptional thermal stability. In this study, the thermal stabilities of AF, AF-SO3H, AF-SN1/2, and AF-SN1/2–10 were evaluated through TG analyses to assess the impact of catalyst preparation and catalytic process. The results, as depicted in Figure S3, indicate that all four fibers exhibit a similar inflection point at approximately 526 °C, suggesting that the catalyst preparation and catalytic process have minimal influence on the fiber's thermal stability. Furthermore, the fiber-supported acid-base bifunctional catalyst demonstrated thermal stability in the majority of reactions. 3.3 Catalytic activities of different catalysts After successfully synthesizing bifunctional fiber catalysts with varying acid-base proportions, their cooperative catalytic activities were compared and screened in the one-pot tandem reaction of benzaldehyde acetal and malononitrile. The results of this comparison are presented in Table 2 . Initially, the reaction was conducted without the use of a catalyst. A mixture of 1.0 mmol benzaldehyde acetal, 1.2 mmol malononitrile, and 5 mL water was stirred at room temperature for 6 h. However, no product was detected under these conditions (Table 2, entry 1). Using AF-SO3H as a catalyst, the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 2.5 h, resulting in a 30% yield of the product (Table 2, entry 2). Subsequently, the acid-base cooperativity of the fiber catalyst was adjusted by varying the acid-base proportions in a model reaction. Under identical conditions, a 41% yield of the product was achieved when AF-SN8/1, with an acid-base proportion of 8:1, was used as the catalyst (Table 2, entry 3). The yield of the reaction initially increases and then decreases with the increase in base content in the bifunctional fiber catalysts. The acid-base ratio was observed to decrease from 4:1 to 1:2, resulting in an increase in yield from 62% to 95% (Table 2, entries 4–7). However, the yield subsequently decreased from 95% to 55% with the continuous increase in the base content of the fiber catalyst (Table 2, entries 7–10). Thus, it can be concluded that the acid-base ratio of 1:2 was the most effective for the bifunctional catalyst, leading to the efficient promotion of the deacetalization-Knoevenagel reaction with a yield of 95%. Subsequently, optimization of catalyst usage and reaction time was also performed. The yield of the reaction decreased to 91% and 88% when the catalyst usage or reaction time was decreased (Table 2, entries 11 and 14). Conversely, increasing the catalyst usage to 7 mol% and 9 mol%, and prolonging the reaction time to 4 h, did not show a positive trend in increasing the yields (Table 2, entries 12, 13 and 15). In summary, the optimized condition for the one-pot tandem deprotection-Knoevenagel reaction was a catalyst usage of 5 mol% of AF-SN1/2 at room temperature in water for 2.5 h. A cooperative mechanism involving AF-SN1/2 catalysis was proposed and elucidated in Scheme S1, wherein a one-pot deacetalization-Knoevenagel reaction takes place. This process comprises two distinct steps: an acid-catalyzed deacetalization and a base-catalyzed formation of the CC bond. Initially, the acetal substrate molecule is activated through protonation by the -SO3H group present in the fiber catalyst, thereby facilitating its subsequent deprotection to yield benzaldehyde. Simultaneously, the adjacent Lewis basic tertiary amine group facilitates the deprotonation of the methylene group within malononitrile. Subsequently, water initiates an attack on the protonated oxonium ion, leading to the liberation of methanol and the formation of protonated benzaldehyde. Following this, a nucleophilic addition occurs between the resultant carbanion and the activated benzaldehyde, culminating in the formation of the ultimate products through a synergistic dehydration process. Following the acquisition of the optimal experimental conditions, an assessment was conducted on the acid-base bifunctional AF catalyst to synthesize a diverse array of α, β-unsaturated compounds, to evaluate the extent of this methodology. The ensuing findings were subsequently documented in Table 3 . It was observed that benzaldehyde acetal could achieve a 95% yield by completing the reaction with malononitrile at RT over a duration of 2.5 h (Table 3, entry 1). Electron-withdrawing group can speed up the reaction, p-chlorobenzaldehyde acetal or p-brmobenzaldehyde acetal coupling with malononitrile with high isolated yields of 96% (Table 3, entries 2 and 3). Conversely, the presence of an electron-donating group (-OMe) hindered the reaction. It was necessary to increase the reaction temperature to 50 °C, and a satisfactory yield of 93% with a TOF value of 9.3 was achieved (Table 3, entry 4). For benzaldehyde diethyl acetal, the reaction time was prolong to 4 h at RT to achieve 93% yield (Table 3, entry 5). And the p-brmoobenzaldehyde diethyl acetal can obtain 95% yield in 3 h at RT (Table 3, entry 6). However, when -Br is in the ortho- or meso‑position of the benzene ring, it is necessary to heat the reaction to 60 °C and maintain it for a period ranging from 3.5 to 4.5 h to attain a yield of either 93% or 91%, respectively (Table 3, entries 7 and 8). Furthermore, when choosing ethyl cyanoacetate as an active hydrogen compound to react with benzaldehyde acetal, only a 23% yield with 0.92 TOF value was obtained (Table 3, entry 9), which further suggested that the AF-supported acid-base bifunctional catalyst system has excellent substrate selectivity. 3.4 Reusability and scaled-up experiments From an economic and sustainable chemistry perspective, reusability is one of the most important factors in evaluating the performance of heterogeneous catalysts. The deacetalization-Knoevenagel reaction of benzaldehyde acetal and malononitrile was chosen as a model reaction to detect the reusability of the catalyst AF-SN1/2. Following the completion of each cycle, the fiber catalyst was effortlessly extracted using conventional tweezers and subsequently washed with water. The recovered AF-SN1/2 was then directly reused for the subsequent cycle without requiring any supplementary treatment. The findings are presented in Fig. 5 . Following the utilization of AF-SN1/2 in ten iterations, the reaction consistently achieved a yield of 91% (no further experimentation conducted), thereby demonstrating the remarkable reusability of the fiber catalyst. Furthermore, the stability of the AF-based acid-base bifunctional catalyst was assessed throughout the investigation, and it was observed that AF-SN1/2 retained its activity even after being stored on shelves for a minimum of three months. Due to its notable mechanical strength and commendable flexibility, the AF catalyst can be readily integrated into various chemical reactors owing to its versatile nature. To showcase the potential industrial applications of the fiber catalyst in the deacetalization-Knoevenagel reaction of benzaldehyde acetal and malononitrile, a straightforward fixed-bed reactor was employed, with the AF-SN1/2 catalyst intertwined on the stirring paddle (Figure S1). The results showed that, when the deacetalization-Knoevenagel reaction was amplified 100 times, it could be finished with a yield of 96% (14.8 g) without any extension of the reaction time, which showed the excellent catalytic activity of the acid-base bifunctional AF catalyst. 3.5 Comparison of the deacetalization-Knoevenagel reaction in different heterogeneous catalytic systems Based on the aforementioned findings, when compared to various heterogeneous catalytic systems operating under their respective optimized experimental conditions for the deacetalization-Knoevenagel reaction involving benzaldehyde acetal and malononitrile (Table 4 ), the acid-base bifunctional AF catalytic system exhibits significant merits in terms of reaction conditions (at room temperature), water phase catalysis, and catalyst reusability (at least 10 cycles). These advantages are notably superior to those observed in numerous previously reported reaction systems. Moreover, the straightforward catalyst preparation procedure and the remarkably facile separation process (which can be accomplished using conventional tweezers) render the AF-based acid-base bifunctional catalyst a compelling substitute for various existing methodologies. 4 Conclusion In summary, a straightforward and effective acid-base bifunctional AF catalyst has been developed through the deliberate adjustment of acid (sulfonic acid group) and base (tertiary amine group) cooperativity to facilitate one-pot tandem deacetalization-Knoevenagel reactions in an aqueous medium. The AF catalyst was synthesized using a straightforward method and subjected to comprehensive characterization, including analysis of its morphology, elemental composition, FTIR spectroscopy, and XRD, among other techniques. Furthermore, a comprehensive investigation was conducted on the acid-base cooperativity of the AF catalysts with various acid-base proportions. Among these catalysts, the AF-SN1/2 exhibited the highest catalytic activity in aqueous conditions. This catalyst effectively facilitated the one-pot tandem reaction of benzaldehyde acetal and malononitrile at room temperature, completing the reaction in 2.5 h with a yield of 95%. Additionally, the AF-SN1/2 mediated system demonstrated remarkable stability, as it did not exhibit a significant decline in catalytic activity even after being recycled over 10 times. Moreover, this system performed exceptionally well in a scaled-up experiment using a simple fixed-bed reactor, achieving a yield of 96%. It turns out that the AF-based acid-base bifunctional catalyst offers numerous advantages, including its straightforward preparation, high activity efficiency, wide substrate applicability, use of environmentally friendly solvents, and exceptional recyclability. By employing this fiber catalytic approach, it becomes possible to design and develop chemical processes that exhibit characteristics of environmental sustainability, cost-effectiveness, and safety, thus paving the way for future advancements in this field. coredata.dc:description: Acid-base bifunctional catalysis represents a significant approach for achieving enzyme-like catalytic activity. In this study, we present a concise and direct approach for constructing acid-base bifunctional aramid fiber catalysts, enabling one-pot tandem deacetalization-Knoevenagel reactions in an aqueous environment. The fiber catalysts were conveniently prepared from commercially available aramid fiber using a straightforward two-step procedure, and comprehensively characterized using various detection techniques. Additionally, the acid-base cooperativity of the AF catalyst was effectively controlled through the manipulation of the acid-base ratios within the catalysts. Notably, the AF-SN1/2 catalyst exhibited superior catalytic activity in the one-pot tandem deprotection-Knoevenagel reaction at room temperature, resulting in the production of high yields. Moreover, the AF-SN1/2 catalyst demonstrated exceptional recyclability and performed admirably in a scaled-up experiment utilizing a straightforward fixed-bed reactor. These findings suggest that the AF-SN1/2 catalyst holds significant promise for future applications in cleaner industrial processes.
